{{About|the radio personality|the attorney|Howard K. Stern}} {{Infobox person |name = Howard Stern |image = Howard Stern.jpg |caption = Howard Stern in May 2012. |birth_name = Howard Allan Stern |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1954|1|12|mf=y}} |religion = |birth_place = [[Jackson Heights, Queens|Jackson Heights]], New York City, United States |death_date = |death_place = |alma_mater = [[Boston University]] |occupation = Radio personality, telejvision host, author, actor, photographer |years_active = 1975–present |spouse = Alison Berns (1978–2001; div.)
[[Beth Ostrosky Stern]] (2008–present) |party = [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] during 1994 [[Governor of New York]] campaign |website = [http://www.howardstern.com/ www.howardstern.com] }} '''Howard Allan Stern''' (born January 12, 1954) is an American radio personality, television host, author, actor, and photographer best known for [[The Howard Stern Show|his radio show]] which was nationally [[Broadcast syndication|syndicated]] from 1986 to 2005. He gained wide recognition in the 1990s and is labeled a "[[shock jock]]" for his outspoken and sometimes controversial style. Stern has been exclusive to [[Sirius XM Radio]], a subscription-based [[satellite radio]] service, since 2006. The son of a former recording and radio engineer, Stern wished to pursue a career in radio at the age of five. While at [[Boston University]] he worked at the campus station [[WTBU]] before a brief stint at [[WNTN]] in [[Newton, Massachusetts]]. He developed his on-air personality when he landed positions at [[WXPK|WRNW]] in [[Briarcliff Manor, New York|Briarcliff Manor]], [[WCCC-FM|WCCC]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]] and [[WDTW-FM|WWWW]] in [[Detroit]]. In 1981, he was paired with his current newscaster and co-host [[Robin Quivers]] at [[WWDC-FM|WWDC]] in Washington, D.C. Stern then moved to [[WNBC (AM)|WNBC]] in New York City in 1982 to host afternoons until his firing in 1985. He re-emerged on [[WXRK]] that year, and became one of the nation's most popular radio personalities during his 20-year tenure at the station. Stern's show is the most-fined radio program, after the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) [[FCC fines of The Howard Stern Show|issued fines]] to station licensees for allegedly indecent material that totaled $2.5 million. Stern has won ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard's]]'' Nationally Syndicated Air Personality of the Year award eight times, and is one of the highest-paid figures in radio.{{cite news|url= http://w3.newsmax.com/radio_hosts.cfm|title=NewsMax Top 25 Radio Hosts|date=November 29, 2008 |publisher= Newsmax |accessdate=November 29, 2008}} Stern describes himself as the '''King of All Media''' for his ventures outside radio. Since 1987, he has hosted numerous late night [[Howard Stern television shows|television shows]], [[Howard Stern videography and discography|pay-per-view events and home video releases]]. He embarked on a five-month political campaign for [[Governor of New York]] in 1994. His two books, ''[[Private Parts (book)|Private Parts]]'' (1993) and ''[[Miss America (book)|Miss America]]'' (1995), spent 20 and 16 weeks respectively on [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''The New York Times'' Best Seller list]]. The former was adapted into ''[[Private Parts (1997 film)|Private Parts]]'' (1997), a biographical comedy film that starred Stern and his radio show [[The Howard Stern Show staff|staff]] that earned $41.2 million in domestic revenue. Stern performs on its [[Howard Stern videography and discography#Private Parts: The Album|soundtrack]] which topped the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart. A published photographer, Stern's work has been featured in a number of magazines including ''[[Hamptons (magazine)|Hamptons]]'' and ''[[WHIRL Magazine|WHIRL]]''. In 2012, Stern became a judge on the television talent show ''[[America's Got Talent]]'', replacing former judge [[Piers Morgan]]. ==Early life and education== [[File:BU College of Communication.jpg|thumb|right|Stern graduated from the College of Public Communications at Boston University in 1976.]] Stern was born on January 12, 1954 into a Jewish family who lived in [[Jackson Heights, Queens]] in New York City.Colford, p. 2.{{cite web |url= http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1098849600 |title= Howard Confronts FCC Chairman Michael Powell! |publisher= howardstern.com |first= Jason |last= Kaplan |accessdate= August 2, 2010 |quote=His Hebrew name is "Tzvi"}} His parents Ben and Ray (née Schiffman) are children of [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] immigrants, and his sister Ellen is four years older than him. The family moved to the hamlet of [[Roosevelt, New York|Roosevelt]] on [[Long Island]] in 1955,Colford, p. 3. where Stern developed an interest in radio at five years of age.Stern, p. 111. While Ray was a homemaker and later an inhalation therapist,Stern, p. 44.Stern, p. 92. Ben was a co-owner of Aura Recording, Inc., a recording studio in [[Manhattan]] where cartoons and commercials were produced.Colford, p. 7. When he made occasional visits with his father, Stern witnessed actors [[Wally Cox]], [[Don Adams]] and [[Larry Storch]] voice his favorite cartoon characters,Stern, p. 113.{{cite news |url= http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0601/05/lkl.01.html |title= CNN Larry King Live - Interview With Howard Stern |publisher= CNN Transcripts | accessdate = March 29, 2010}} which influenced him to later talk on the air rather than play records.Stern, p. 114. Ben was also an engineer at [[WZRC|WHOM]], a radio station in Manhattan. Upon completion of [[sixth grade]], Stern left Washington-Rose Elementary School for [[Roosevelt Junior-Senior High School]].Colford, p. 9. In June 1969, the family moved to nearby [[Rockville Centre, New York|Rockville Centre]] and Stern transferred to [[South Side High School (Rockville Centre, New York)|South Side High School]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sirius.com/servlet/ContentServer?pagename=Sirius/Page&c=FlexContent&cid=1198688730431 |title=The History of Howard Stern Act I Interactive Guide |publisher = Sirius Satellite Radio | date=December 2007 | accessdate= August 2, 2010}} Stern spent the first two of four years at [[Boston University]] in the College of Basic Studies.Stern, p. 115. In 1973, he started to work at [[WTBU]], the campus radio station where he spun records, read the news, and hosted interviews. He also hosted a comedy program with three fellow students called ''The King Schmaltz Bagel Hour''.Stern, pp. 115–117. Stern gained admission to the [[Boston University College of Communication|School of Public Communications]] in 1974Colford, p. 31. and earned a diploma in July 1975 at the Radio Engineering Institute of Electronics in [[Fredericksburg, Virginia]] which allowed him to apply for a [[General radiotelephone operator license|first class FCC radio-telephone license]].Stern, p. 121.{{cite news |url= http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VWQzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tgcGAAAAIBAJ&pg=4720%2C66309 |title= Stern's Start |work= The Free Lance-Star |first= Michael |last= Zitz |date= July 1, 1994 |accessdate= May 14, 2010}} With the license, Stern made his professional debut at [[WNTN]] in [[Newton, Massachusetts]], performing airshift, newscasting and production duties between August and December 1975.Stern, p. 123. He graduated [[Latin honors#Types|magna cum laude]] from Boston University in May 1976 with a degree in Communications and now funds a scholarship at the university.{{cite web |url=http://www.bu.edu/bulletins/com/item19.html |title=Boston University 2009-10 College of Communication Bulletin |publisher=Boston University | accessdate= August 2, 2010}} ==Career== {{See also|The Howard Stern Show|Howard Stern television shows|Howard Stern videography and discography}} ===Early professional radio career (1976–1981)=== After his graduation in 1976, Stern declined an offer to work evenings at [[WXPK|WRNW]], a [[progressive rock]] station in [[Briarcliff Manor]], [[Westchester County, New York]].Stern, p. 118. He was unsure of his talent, and questioned his future in the professional industry. Stern took creative and media planning roles at [[Benton & Bowles]], a New York advertising agency, followed by a job in selling radio time to advertisers.Stern, pp. 118–119. He realized the mistake of declining on-air work and contacted WRNW a second time where he agreed to work covering shifts over the Christmas holiday period.Stern, p. 119. Stern was hired full-time in 1977 and worked a four-hour midday shift, six days per week a $96 weekly salary. He subsequently worked as the station's production and [[program director]] for an increased salary of $250.Stern, p. 122. In 1979, Stern spotted an advertisement for a "wild, fun morning guy" at rock station [[WCCC-FM|WCCC]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut]].Stern, p. 125. He submitted a more outrageous audition tape with [[Robert Klein]] and [[Cheech and Chong]] records mixed with flatulence routines and one-liners.Colford, p. 45. Stern was hired with no change in salary with a more intense schedule. After four hours on the air he voiced and produced commercials for another four. On Saturdays, following a six-hour show, he did production work for the next three. As the station's public affairs director he also hosted a Sunday morning talk show which he favoured.Stern, pp. 126–127. In the summer of the [[1979 energy crisis]], Stern held a two-day boycott of [[Shell Oil Company]] which attracted media attention.Colford, p. 48. Stern left WCCC a year later after he was declined a pay increase.Stern, p. 128. [[Fred Norris]], the overnight disc jockey, has been Stern's producer and writer since 1981.Colford, p. 74. Management at rock outlet [[WDTW-FM|WWWW]] in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] praised Stern's audition tape in their search for a new morning man.Colford, p. 52. Stern was hired for the job which he started on April 21, 1980. He learned to become more open on the air and "decided to cut down the barriers...strip down all the ego...and be totally honest", he later told ''[[Newsday]]''.Colford, p. 57. His efforts earned him a ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' award for "Album-Oriented Rock Personality of the Year For a Major Market" and the [[Drake-Chenault]] "Top Five Talent Search" title.{{cite news | title=Billboard's Radio Winners Named | date=August 1, 1981 | work= Billboard | accessdate = February 14, 2010 |url= http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ASQEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PT2&dq=%22Radio%20Winners%20Named%22&rview=1&pg=PT2#v=onepage&q=%22Radio%20Winners%20Named%22&f=false}}Stern, p. 134. The station, however, ran into problems after Stern's quarterly [[Arbitron]] ratings had decreased while it struggled to compete with its stronger rock competitors. In January 1981, WWWW switched to a country music [[radio format|format]] much to Stern's dislike, who left the station soon after.Colford, p. 61. He received offers to work at [[WXRT]] in [[Chicago]] and [[CHUM-FM|CHUM]] in [[Toronto]], but did not take them.{{cite news | title= Stern warning | date= September 4, 1997 | first= Jeff | last= Craig | publisher= Jam! | accessdate = August 12, 2010 |url= http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Artists/S/Stern_Howard/1997/09/04/761973.html}} ===Washington and WNBC New York (1981–1985)=== Stern moved to Washington, D.C. to host mornings at rock station [[WWDC (FM)|WWDC]] on March 2, 1981.Colford, p. 62.Colford, p. 67. He wanted to develop his show further, and looked for a co-worker with a sense of humor to riff with on news and current events.Stern, p. 135. The station paired Stern with [[Robin Quivers]], a newscaster and consumer affairs reporter from [[WJZ (AM)|WFBR]] in [[Baltimore]].Colford, p. 63. Though he felt restricted and controlled by management who enforced a strict format, Stern had the second highest rated morning radio program in January 1982.Stern, pp. 138–140.Colford, p. 78. Impressed with his ratings success, [[NBC]] approached Stern with an offer to work afternoons at [[WNBC (AM)|WNBC]] in New York City. After Stern signed a five-year contract worth $1 million in March,Colford, p. 81. his relationship with WWDC management worsened,Colford, p. 85. and his contract with the station was terminated on June 25. He had more than tripled the station's morning ratings during his stay.Colford, pp. 87–89. In its July issue ''[[Washingtonian (magazine)|The Washingtonian]]'' named Stern the area's best disc jockey.Colford, p. 89. Stern released ''[[50 Ways to Rank Your Mother]]'', a comedy album of his radio bits. The record was re-released as ''Unclean Beaver'' in November 1994.Colford, p. 82. On April 2, 1982, a news report by [[Douglas Kiker]] on raunch radio featuring Stern aired on ''NBC Magazine''.Colford, pp. 91–93. The piece stimulated discussion among NBC management to withdraw Stern's contract. When he began his afternoon program in September,{{cite news | title= WNBC's Stern Is Rendered Speechless | date= September 11, 1982 | work= Billboard |accessdate = February 25, 2010 |url= http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OiQEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PT15&dq=%22howard%20stern%22&rview=1&pg=PT15#v=onepage&q=%22howard%20stern%22&f=false}} management closely monitored Stern, telling him to avoid talk of a sexual and religious nature.{{cite news |url = http://books.google.com/books?id=3-QCAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA38#v=onepage&q&f=false |title = Bad Mouth. Howard Stern vs The FCC |work = New York Magazine |date = November 23, 1992 |accessdate = August 19, 2010 |first= Jeanie |last= Kasindorf }} In his first month, Stern was suspended for several days for "Virgin Mary Kong", a segment featuring a video game where a group of men pursued the [[Virgin Mary]] around a singles bar in Jerusalem. An attorney was hired to man a "[[broadcast delay|dump button]]", and cut Stern off the microphone should potentially offensive areas be discussed. This became the task of program director [[Kevin Metheny]], who Stern nicknamed "Pig Virus". On May 21, 1984, Stern made his first appearance on ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'', launching him into the national spotlight. A year later he claimed the highest ratings at WNBC in four years with a 5.7% market share.Colford, p. 128. On September 30, 1985, Stern and Quivers were fired for what management termed "conceptual differences" regarding the show. "Over the course of time, we made a very conscious effort to make Stern aware that certain elements of the program should be changed...I don't think it's appropriate to say what those specifics were",Luerssen, p. 12. said program director [[John Hayes (radio)|John Hayes]], who Stern nicknamed "The Incubus". In 1992, Stern believed Thornton Bradshaw, chairman of WNBC's owner [[RCA]], heard his "Bestiality Dial-a-Date" segment and ordered his firing. Stern and Quivers kept in touch with their audience throughout October and November where they toured club venues with a stage show.{{cite web |url = http://www.sirius.com/wo/i/howard/history_II/part_a/hoh-120908_a.swf |title = The History of Howard Stern Act II Interactive Guide |publisher = Sirius Satellite Radio |date=December 2008 |accessdate=November 16, 2010}} ===K-Rock, early television endeavors and Fartman (1985–1992)=== Stern signed a contract with [[Infinity Broadcasting]] worth around $500,000Colford, pp. 147–148. and returned to afternoons on its New York rock station [[WXRK]] on November 18, 1985. The show moved to mornings on February 18, 1986 and entered national [[broadcast syndication|syndication]] on August 18 when [[WIP-FM|WYSP]] in [[Philadelphia]] first simulcast the program. In October 1992, Stern became the first to have the number one morning radio show in New York and Los Angeles simultaneously.{{cite news | title = Letterman gives NBC a good-faith reprieve | work = Chicago Tribune |date= October 31, 1992 | quote = Stern, whose morning madhouse is simulcast in nine markets, is the first deejay to top the ratings simultaneously in New York and Los Angeles.}} In the New York market ''The Howard Stern Show'' was the highest-rated morning program for seven consecutive years between 1994 and 2001.{{cite news | url= http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2001/04/23/2001-04-23_hot-97_returns_to_the_top.html |title= Hot-97 Returns To The Top |last= Hinkley |first= David |work= [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |date= April 23, 2001 |accessdate= September 1, 2010}} In 1994, ''Billboard'' magazine added the "Nationally Syndicated Air Personality of the Year" category to its annual radio awards based on entertainment value, creativity and ratings success.{{cite news | title = Honoring Best In Broadcasting | date = October 21, 2000 | work= Billboard | accessdate = July 20, 2010 |url = http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QBIEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA89&dq=%22howard%20stern%22%20%22personality%20of%20the%20year%22&pg=PA89#v=onepage&q=%22howard%20stern%22%20%22personality%20of%20the%20year%22&f=false}} Stern was awarded the title from 1994 to 2002.{{cite news | title = WLTW, KKBT, KROQ, WQYK Lead Billboard Radio Awards | first = Steven | last = Graybow | date = March 30, 2002 | work = Billboard | accessdate = July 20, 2010 |url = http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jRAEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA78&dq=%22howard%20stern%22%20%22personality%20of%20the%20year%22%20%222001%22&pg=PA78#v=onepage&q=%22howard%20stern%22%20%22personality%20of%20the%20year%22%20%222001%22&f=false}}{{cite news | title = Radio Awards Dial Up First-Time Winners | first = Steven | last = Graybow | date = February 22, 2003 | work= Billboard | accessdate = March 26, 2010 |url = http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CA8EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA47&dq=%22howard%20stern%22%20%22personality%20of%20the%20year%22&pg=PA47#v=onepage&q=%22howard%20stern%22%20%22personality%20of%20the%20year%22&f=false}} In May 1987, Stern recorded [[Howard Stern television shows#The Howard Stern Show (Fox)|five television pilots]] for [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] when the network planned to replace ''[[The Late Show (1986 TV series)|The Late Show]]'' hosted by [[Joan Rivers]].Colford, p. 181. The series was never picked up; one executive having described the show as "poorly produced", "in poor taste" and "boring".{{cite news |last=Kubasik |first=Ben |title= TV Spots |work= Newsday |date= August 12, 1987 |accessdate= August 19, 2010 | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/newsday/access/104577134.html?dids=104577134:104577134&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+12%2C+1987&author=By+Ben+Kubasik&pub=Newsday+%28Combined+editions%29&desc=TV+SPOTS&pqatl=google}} Stern hosted his first pay-per-view event on February 27, 1988 named ''[[Howard Stern videography and discography#Howard Stern's Negligeé and Underpants Party|Howard Stern's Negligeé and Underpants Party]]''. Over 60,000 homes purchased the two-hour special that grossed $1.2 million.Colford, p. 186. On September 7, 1989, over 16,000 fans packed out [[Nassau Coliseum]] for ''[[Howard Stern videography and discography#Howard Stern's U.S. Open Sores|Howard Stern's U.S. Open Sores]]'', a live event that featured a tennis match between Stern and his radio show producer, [[Gary Dell'Abate]]. Both events were released for home video. From 1990 to 1992, Stern was the host of ''[[Howard Stern television shows#The Howard Stern Show (WWOR-TV)|The Howard Stern Show]]'', a Saturday night program on [[WWOR-TV]]. The series ran for 69 episodes to 65 markets nationwide.Colford, pp. 197–201. In February 1991, Stern released ''[[Crucified by the FCC]]'', a collection of censored radio segments following the [[FCC fines of The Howard Stern Show#Revised indecency standard and first fine .281985.E2.80.931990.29|first fine]] issued to Infinity by the FCC over alleged indecency.{{cite web | title = The History of Howard Stern Act III On-Air Schedule | publisher = Sirius Satellite Radio | url = http://www.sirius.com/servlet/ContentServer?pagename=Sirius/Page&c=FlexContent&cid=1258752021436 |date = December 2009 |accessdate = January 10, 2010 }} He released a third video tape, ''[[Butt Bongo Fiesta]]'', in October 1992 that sold 260,000 copies for a gross of over $10 million. He returned to Saturday night television that November with ''[[Howard Stern television shows#The Howard Stern Interview|The Howard Stern "Interview"]]'', a one-on-one celebrity interview series on [[E!]].{{citation needed|date=March 2011}} Stern appeared at the [[1992 MTV Video Music Awards]] as [[Fartman (Howard Stern)|Fartman]], a fictional superhero that first appeared in the ''[[National Lampoon (magazine)|National Lampoon]]'' humor magazine series. According to the trademark he filed for the character that October, he first used Fartman in July 1981.{{cite web |url=http://tarr.uspto.gov/servlet/tarr?regser=serial&entry=74323667 |title= Fartman Trademark |publisher= United States Patent and Trademark Office |date=October 16, 1992 |accessdate=April 8, 2011}} Stern rejected multiple scripts for a proposed summer 1993 release of ''The Adventures of Fartman'' until a verbal agreement was reached with [[New Line Cinema]].Colford, p. 202. Screenwriter [[J. F. Lawton]] had prepared a script before relations soured over the film's rating, content and merchandising rights and the project was abandoned.{{cite news |last=Brennan |first=Judy |title= Stern's New Year's Party Fallout `The Miss Howard Stern Pageant' was a pay-TV bonanza but may have cost him a movie career |work= The Los Angeles Time |date= January 30, 1994 | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/59301264.html?dids=59301264:59301264&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+30%2C+1994&author=JUDY+BRENNAN&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Stern%27s+New+Year%27s+Party+Fallout+%60The+Miss+Howard+Stern+Pageant%27+was+a+pay-TV+bonanza+but+may+have+cost+him+a+movie+career&pqatl=google |accessdate= May 7, 2010}}{{cite news | first = Stephen | last = Schaefer | title = Running Out of Gas | work = Entertainment Weekly | date = May 7, 1993 | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,306478,00.html |accessdate= May 7, 2010 }} ===''Private Parts'', E! show and run for Governor (1993–1994)=== In 1993, Stern signed a $1 million advance contract with [[Simon & Schuster]] to publish his first book.Colford, pp. 222–223. Co-authored with [[Larry Sloman]] and edited by [[Judith Regan]], the release of ''[[Private Parts (book)|Private Parts]]'' on October 7 saw its first printing of 225,000 copies being sold within hours of going on sale. It became the fastest-selling title in the history of Schuster after five days.{{cite news | title = Stern's 'Private Parts' Tops Limbaugh's Mark | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WE&s_site=kansas&p_multi=WE&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADB5AD4BD7B3C3&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work = The Wichita Eagle | quote = "Five days after its publication, "Private Parts" had become the fastest-selling book in the 70-year history of Simon & Schuster." |date=October 20, 1993 |accessdate= August 20, 2010}} In its eighth printing two weeks later, over one million copies had been distributed.Colford, p. 222-223. Stern embarked on a book signing tour that attracted an estimated 10,000 fans at a [[Barnes & Noble]] store on [[Fifth Avenue]] in New York. In its first run, ''Private Parts'' spent 20 weeks on [[New York Times Best Seller list|''The New York Times'' Best-Seller list]].{{cite news|url = http://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/11/business/media/11stern.html |first = Bill |last = Carter |title = Where Some See Just a Shock Jock, Sirius Sees a Top Pitchman |accessdate = April 8, 2010 |date= October 11, 2004 | work = The New York Times }} Stern has written forewords for ''Steal This Dream'' (1998), a biography of [[Abbie Hoffman]], ''Disgustingly Dirty Joke Book'' (1998) by [[Jackie Martling]], ''[[Too Fat to Fish]]'' (2008) by [[Artie Lange]], and ''Dear Mrs. Fitzsimmons: Tales of Redemption from an Irish Mailbox'' (2010) by [[Greg Fitzsimmons]]. Stern hosted his second pay-per-view event, ''[[Howard Stern videography and discography#The Miss Howard Stern New Year's Eve Pageant|The Miss Howard Stern New Year's Eve Pageant]]'', on December 31, 1993. It broke the subscriber record for a non-sports event previously held by a [[New Kids on the Block]] concert in 1990.{{cite news |url = http://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/24/business/he-keeps-giving-new-meaning-to-gross-revenue.html?pagewanted=all |last=Mills |first=Joshua |title = He Keeps Giving New Meaning To Gross Revenue |work = The New York Times |date = October 24, 1993 |accessdate= May 5, 2010}} Around 400,000 households purchased the event that grossed an estimated $16 million.{{cite news |url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,300879,00.html |last=Svetkey |first=Benjamin |title = Stern Spurned |work = Entertainment Weekly |date = January 21, 1994 |accessdate= August 20, 2010}} Stern released the program on VHS in early 1994 as ''Howard Stern's New Year's Rotten Eve 1994''. Between his book royalties and pay-per-view profits, Stern's earnings in the latter months of 1993 totalled around $7.5 million.Colford, p. 226. In its 20th anniversary issue in 1993, ''Radio & Records'' named Stern the most influential air personality of the past two decades.Colford, p. 254. On March 21, 1994, Stern announced his candidacy for [[Governor of New York]] under the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] ticket, challenging [[Mario Cuomo]] for re-election.Colford, p. 232. He planned to reinstate the death penalty, stagger highway tolls to improve traffic flow, and limit road work to night hours.{{cite news | title = Stern Message | date = July 1994 | work= Reason | url = http://www.reason.com/news/show/29472.html | first= Nick | last= Gillespie |accessdate= August 20, 2010}} At the party's nomination convention in Albany on April 23, Stern won the required two-thirds majority on the first ballot, receiving 287 of the 381 votes cast (75.33%). James Ostrowski finished second with 34 votes (8.92%).{{cite web | title = LBT Convention Race - April 23, 1994| date = April 23, 1994 | url = http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=93072 | author = Our Campaigns |accessdate= August 20, 2010}} To place his name on the November ballot, Stern was obliged to state his home address and to complete a financial disclosure form under the [[Ethics in Government Act]] of 1987. After declining to disclose his financial information, Stern was denied an injunction on August 2.Colford, p. 243. He withdrew his candidacy two days later. Cuomo was defeated in the [[New York gubernatorial election, 1994|gubernatorial election]] on November 8 by [[George Pataki]], who Stern backed. Pataki signed "The Howard Stern Bill" that limited construction on state roads to night hours in New York and Long Island, in 1995.{{cite news | title = 'Stern' Bill Is Signed, Pataki OKs Night Road Work | date = August 3, 1995 | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DN&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI|DN&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB2A2875FF3D563&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work = Philadelphia Daily News | accessdate= May 7, 2010}} In June 1994, robotic cameras were installed at WXRK studios to film ''The Howard Stern Show'' for a condensed half-hour show on E!.{{cite news | title = Howard Stern to Star, Condensed, on TV | date = June 1, 1994 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/01/arts/howard-stern-to-star-condensed-on-tv.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate= July 29, 2010 }} ''[[Howard Stern (E! show)|Howard Stern]]'' ran for 11 years until the last taped episode aired on July 8, 2005.{{cite news | title = Stern cancels E! ticket | first = Denise | last = Martin | date = June 21, 2005 | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117924855.html?cs=1&s=h&p=0 | work = Variety | accessdate= July 29, 2010 }} In conjunction with his move to satellite radio, Stern launched [[Howard Stern On Demand|Howard Stern on Demand]], a subscription [[video-on-demand]] service, on November 18.{{cite news | title = 'On Demand' Will Bare More Of Stern Footage | first = Richard | last = Huff | date = November 17, 2005 | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2005/11/17/2005-11-17__on_demand__will_bare_more_o.html | work = [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] | accessdate= July 29, 2010 }} The service was relaunched as Howard TV on March 16, 2006.{{cite news | title = Hangin' With Howard | first = Josh | last = Wolk | date = March 31, 2005 | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1177593,00.html | work = Entertainment Weekly | accessdate= July 29, 2010 }} ===''Miss America'' and ''Private Parts'' film (1995–1997)=== On April 3, 1995, three days after the shooting of singer [[Selena]], Stern's comments regarding her death and [[Mexican Americans]] caused an uproar in the [[Hispanic]] community. He criticized her music and gunfire sound effects were played over her songs. "This music does absolutely nothing for me. [[Alvin and the Chipmunks]] have more soul...Spanish people have the worst taste in music. They have no depth".{{cite news | first = Stephanie | last = Asin | title = Selena's Public Outraged: Shock Jock Howard Stern's Comments Hit Raw Nerve | url = http://www.chron.com/content/chronicle/metropolitan/selena/95/04/06/stern.html | work = Houston Chronicle | date = April 6, 1995 | accessdate = February 1, 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070710182116/http://www.chron.com/content/chronicle/metropolitan/selena/95/04/06/stern.html |archivedate = July 10, 2007}} On April 6, Stern responded with a statement in Spanish, stressing his comments were made in satire and not intended to hurt those who loved her.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?id=S8YRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uOwDAAAAIBAJ&dq=howard%20stern%20selena&pg=1854%2C3274507 |title= Satire triggers a Stern outcry, puts 'shock jock' on defensive |date=April 6, 1995 |accessdate=September 2, 2010 |work=The Deseret News}} A day later, [[Justice of the Peace]] Eloy Cano of [[Harlingen, Texas]] issued an arrest warrant on Stern for disorderly conduct.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1995/04/13/1995-04-13_judge_wants_stern_to_face_mu.html |title= Judge Wants Stern To Face Music For Selena Comments |date=April 13, 1995 |accessdate=September 2, 2010 |first=David |last=Hinckley |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] }} In 1995, Stern signed a deal with [[ReganBooks]] worth $3 million to write his second book, ''[[Miss America (book)|Miss America]]''.Colford, pp. 265–266. He wrote about his [[cybersex]] experiences on the [[Prodigy (online service)|Prodigy]] service, a private meeting with [[Michael Jackson]], and his suffering with [[obsessive-compulsive disorder]].{{cite news | title = Miss America (1996) | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,299731,00.html | work = Entertainment Weekly | accessdate = August 24, 2010 | date = December 1, 1995 | first = A.J. | last = Jacobs }} Released on November 7, the book sold 33,000 copies at [[Barnes & Noble]] stores on the same day which set a new one-day record.{{cite news | url = http://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/15/books/book-notes-038580.html | date = November 15, 1995 | first = Mary | last = Tabor | title = Stern Guns Down Powell Book | accessdate = August 1, 2010 | work = The New York Times }} ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' reported over 1.39 million copies were sold by the year's end and ranked it the third best-selling book of 1995.Lucaire, p. 145. ''Miss America'' spent a total of 16 weeks on ''The New York Times'' best-seller list. Production for a [[Private Parts (1997 film)|film adaptation]] of ''Private Parts'' began in May 1996 with all shooting complete in four months.Colford, p. 268. Its premiere was held at The Theatre at [[Madison Square Garden]] on February 27, 1997, where Stern performed "[[The Great American Nightmare]]" with [[Rob Zombie]].{{cite news | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1997/02/27/1997-02-27__private_parts__a_public_has.html | date = February 27, 1997 | first = Denene | last = Millner | title = 'Private Parts' a Public Hassle | accessdate = August 1, 2010 | work = [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]}} Making its general release on March 7, ''Private Parts'' topped the box office sales in its opening weekend with a gross of $14.6 million, and went on to earn a total of $41.2 million in domestic gross revenue.{{cite web | title = Private Parts | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=privateparts.htm | publisher = Box Office Mojo | accessdate = April 3, 2010 }} The film holds a "fresh" rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], a website that [[review aggregator|aggregates film reviews]]. 79% of critics gave ''Private Parts'' a positive review based on a sample of 48 reviews, with an average score of 6.6 out of 10.{{cite web | title = Private Parts (1997)| url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1075777-private_parts/ | accessdate = April 3, 2010 | publisher = Rotten Tomatoes}} For his performance, Stern won a [[Blockbuster Inc.|Blockbuster]] Entertainment Award for "Favorite Male Newcomer" and was nominated for a [[Satellite Awards|Golden Satellite Award]] for "Best Performance by an Actor in a Motion Picture (Comedy)" and a [[Golden Raspberry Award]] for "Worst New Star".{{citation needed|date=March 2011}} The [[Howard Stern videography and discography#Private Parts: The Album|soundtrack]] to ''Private Parts'' sold 178,000 copies in its first week of release, topping the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] [[List of number-one albums of 1997 (U.S.)|chart]].{{cite web | url = http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1434630/19970307/stern_howard.jhtml | date = March 7, 1997 | title = Stern Talks About Chart-Topping Soundtrack | accessdate = August 1, 2010 | publisher = MTV News }} Stern filed a $1.5 million lawsuit against Ministry of Film Inc. in October 1997, claiming it recruited him for a film titled ''Jane'' starring [[Melanie Griffith]] while knowing it had insufficient funds. Stern, who was unpaid when production ceased, accused the studio of breach of contract, fraud and negligent representation.{{cite news | title = Stern sues movie studio, says it reneged on deal | date = October 10, 1997 | url = http://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?id=pVMgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pM8EAAAAIBAJ&dq=howard-stern%20jane%20melanie-griffith&pg=5002%2C2100880 | work = Spartanburg Herald-Journal | accessdate = July 28, 2010 }} A settlement was reached in 1999 with Stern receiving $50,000.{{cite news | title = Studio avoids court by giving Stern $50,000 | date = August 25, 1999 | url = http://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?id=fkAgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6H0EAAAAIBAJ&dq=howard-stern%20jane%20melanie-griffith&pg=6293%2C6608896 | work = Saratosa Herald-Tribune | accessdate = July 28, 2010 }} ===Return to Saturday night television and productions (1998–2004)=== In August 1998, Stern returned to Saturday night television with ''[[The Howard Stern Radio Show]]''.{{cite web |url= http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Artists/S/Stern_Howard/1998/04/01/761968.html |first= John |last= Sakamoto |title= Stern's TV show to debut in August |date= April 1, 1998 |publisher= Jam! Showbiz |accessdate= April 9, 2010}} Broadcast across the country on [[CBS]] affiliates, it featured radio show highlights along with material unseen in his nightly E! show. The show competed for ratings with comedy shows ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' on NBC and ''[[MADtv]]'' on Fox. Concerned with its risqué content, affiliates began to leave the show after two episodes.{{cite news |url= http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1998/09/02/1998-09-02_texas_tv_station_boots__ster.html |first= Eric |last= Mink |title= Texas TV Station Boots 'Stern' |work= [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |date= September 2, 1998 |accessdate= April 9, 2010}} Making its launch on 79 stations on August 22, 1998, this number was reduced to 55 by June 1999.Luerssen, p. 148. A total of 84 episodes were broadcast.{{citation needed|date=March 2011}} The final re-run aired on November 17, 2001, to around 30 markets.{{cite news |url= http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2001/11/15/2001-11-15_inner_tube.html |first= Donna |last= Petrozzello |title= Stern Going Off The Air |work= [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |date= November 15, 2001 |accessdate= April 9, 2010}}{{cite news |url= http://www.mediapost.com/publications/?fa=Articles.printFriendly&art_aid=13521# |title= Howard Stern's Radio Show Leaving TV |work= Media Post News |date= November 16, 2001 |accessdate= April 9, 2010}} In 1994, Stern launched the Howard Stern Production Company for original and joint production and development ventures. He intended to make a film adaptation of ''Brother Sam'', the biography of the late comedian [[Sam Kinison]].{{cite news |url= http://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?id=KOcTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-gcEAAAAIBAJ&dq=howard-stern-production&pg=4647%2C1535965 |title= Entertainment News |work= Star-Banner |date= June 24, 1994 |accessdate= April 9, 2010}} In September 1999, [[UPN]] announced the production of ''Doomsday'', an animated science-fiction comedy series executively produced by Stern.{{cite news |url= http://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?id=pyIyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b6YFAAAAIBAJ&dq=doomsday%20howard-stern&pg=3357%2C1102446 |title= Stern's 'Doomsday' dawns at UPN |work= Reading Eagle |date= September 17, 1999 |accessdate= August 24, 2010}} Originally set for a 2000 release, Stern starred as Orinthal, a family dog.{{cite news |url= http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1999/09/16/1999-09-16_upn_show_enlists_stern_as_an.html |title= UPN Show Enlists Stern As An Animated Talker |work= [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |date= September 16, 1999 |accessdate= August 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes}} {{Dead link|date=August 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} The project was eventually abandoned. From 2000 to 2002, Stern was the executive producer of ''[[Son of the Beach]]'', a sitcom which ran for three seasons on [[FX (TV network)|FX]]. In late 2001, Howard Stern Productions was reportedly developing a new sitcom titled ''Kane''.{{cite news |url= http://www.animaux.net/stern/kane.html |first= Michael |last= Schneider |title= Stern, CBS part for sitcom |agency=Reuters |date= November 16, 2001 |accessdate= April 9, 2010}} The pilot episode was never filmed. In 2002, Stern acquired the rights to comedy films ''[[Rock 'n' Roll High School]]'' (1979) and ''[[Porky's]]'' (1982). He filed a $100 million lawsuit in March 2003 against [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] and the producers of ''[[Are You Hot?]]'', claiming the series was based on his radio segment called "The Evaluators". A settlement was reached on August 7.{{cite news |url= http://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?id=FZwyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8-gFAAAAIBAJ&dq=howard%20stern%20telepictures%20productions&pg=6213%2C5926462 |title= 'Are You Hot?' suit settled |work= Lawrence Journal-World |date= August 10, 2003 |accessdate= August 20, 2010}} Stern announced in early 2004 of talks with ABC to host a prime time interview special, which never materialized. In August 2004, cable channel [[Spike (TV channel)|Spike]] picked up 13 episodes of ''Howard Stern: The High School Years'', a second animated series Stern was to executive produce.{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/3589164.stm |title= DJ Stern to star in own cartoon |work= BBC News |date= August 22, 2004 |accessdate= August 24, 2010}} On November 14, 2005, Stern announced the completion of episode scripts and 30 seconds of test animations.{{cite web |url= http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1131944400 |title= Howard Gets Animated |publisher= howardstern.com |date= November 14, 2005 |first= Jason |last= Kaplan |accessdate= August 24, 2010}} Stern eventually gave the project up. In 2007, he explained the episodes could have been produced "on the cheap" at $300,000 each, though the quality he demanded would have cost over $1 million.{{cite web |url= http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1189396800 |title= Very Dark For A Cartoon |publisher= howardstern.com |date= September 10, 2007 |first= Jason |last= Kaplan |accessdate= August 24, 2010}} Actor [[Michael Cera]] was cast as the lead voice.{{cite web |url= http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1262667600 |title= Today's Show Companion |publisher= howardstern.com |date= January 5, 2010 |first= Jason |last= Kaplan |accessdate= August 24, 2010}} ===Satellite radio and ''America's Got Talent'' (2004–present)=== [[File:Howard 100 News Team, Winter 2005-2006.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Following Stern's move to Sirius, he assembled the Howard 100 News team.]] On October 6, 2004, Stern announced the signing of a five-year contract with [[Sirius Satellite Radio]], a medium free from FCC regulations, that started in January 2006.{{cite web |url= http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?j=p&d=1097121600 |title= Howard To Sirius Satellite In '06 - Predicts End Of Broadcast Radio! |publisher= howardstern.com |first= Jason |last= Kaplan |date= October 6, 2004 |accessdate= August 20, 2010}} His decision to leave terrestrial radio occurred in the aftermath of the [[Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy|controversy]] surrounding the [[Super Bowl XXXVIII]] halftime show in February that caused a crackdown on perceived indecency in broadcasting. The incident prompted tighter control over content by station owners and managers to which Stern felt "dead inside" creatively.{{cite news | first = Howard | last = Kurtz | title = Stern On Satellite: A Bruised Flower, Blossoming Anew | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/12/10/AR2005121001432.html | work = The Washington Post | date= December 11, 2005 | accessdate = September 18, 2009 }} Stern hosted his final broadcast on terrestrial airwaves on December 16, 2005.{{cite web | url=http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?month=December&day=16&year=2005 |title= The Last Rundown (On FM) |last= Kaplan |first= Jason |publisher= howardstern.com |date= December 16, 2005 |accessdate= March 3, 2010}} During his 20 years at WXRK his show had syndicated in 60 markets{{cite news | last = Deggans | first = Eric | title = Bubba, relaunched | work = St. Petersburg Times |date= December 11, 2005 | url = http://www.sptimes.com/2005/12/11/Artsandentertainment/Bubba__relaunched.shtml}}{{cite web | last = Tucker | first = Ken | title = Communication Sharpens Syndie Sword | work = Billboard Radio Monitor |date= March 3, 2006 | url = http://www.allbusiness.com/services/motion-pictures/4488183-1.html}} across the United States and Canada and gained a peak audience of 20 million listeners.{{cite news | last = Condran | first = Ed | title = Stern Producer Flourishes By The Skin Of His Teeth | work = The Morning Call |date= July 31, 1998 | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/mcall/access/32538396.html?dids=32538396:32538396&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+31%2C+1998&author=ED+CONDRAN+%28A+free-lance+story+for+The+Morning+Call%29&pub=Morning+Call&desc=STERN+PRODUCER+FLOURISHES+BY+THE+SKIN+OF+HIS+TEETH&pqatl=google}}{{cite news | last = James | first = Renee | title = Hmmm? Stern's critics are plugged into regular radio | work = The Morning Call |date= October 1, 2006 | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/mcall/access/1139172241.html?dids=1139172241:1139172241&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+01%2C+2006&author=Renee+A.+James%2C+Special+to+The+Morning+Call+-+Freelance&pub=Morning+Call&desc=Hmmm%3F+Stern%27s+critics+are+plugged+into+regular+radio&pqatl=google}}{{cite news | last = Sullivan | first = James | title = Love him or hate him, Stern is a true pioneer | publisher = MSNBC |date= December 14, 2005 | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/10454035/from/RSS/}} With an annual budget of $100 million for all production, staff and programming costs, Stern launched two channels on Sirius in 2005 named [[Howard 100 and Howard 101]]. He assembled the [[Howard 100 News]] team that covered stories about his show and those associated with it, and a new dedicated studio was constructed at Sirius' headquarters in New York.{{cite web | url = http://www.secinfo.com/dsvRa.13ej.htm | title = Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. 8-K For 10/1/04 | publisher = SEC Info | date = October 1, 2004 | accessdate = March 25, 2010 }} On January 9, 2006, the day of his first broadcast, Stern and his agent received 34.3 million shares of stock from the company worth $218 million for exceeding subscriber targets set in 2004.{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/2006/01/05/news/newsmakers/stern/index.htm | title=Howard Stern & Co. Score $200M Payout | work=CNN Money | date=January 5, 2006 | accessdate=July 26, 2006}} A second stock incentive was paid in 2007, with Stern receiving 22 million shares worth $82.9 million.{{cite news | title= Howard Stern wins $83M bonus from Sirius | url= http://www.cbc.ca/arts/media/story/2007/01/09/stern-satellite.html | work= CBC News | date= January 9, 2007 | accessdate= August 25, 2010}} On February 28, 2006, [[CBS Radio]] (formerly Infinity Broadcasting) filed a lawsuit against Stern, his agent and Sirius. The suit claimed Stern had misused CBS broadcast time to promote Sirius for unjust enrichment during the last 14 months of his terrestrial radio contract.{{cite news |url= http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2006/03/01/stern-lawsuit-cbs.html |title= CBS Radio files lawsuit against Stern, Sirius |date= March 1, 2006 |publisher= CBS News |accessdate= May 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes}} {{Dead link|date=August 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}{{cite news | title= CBS Radio Files Lawsuit Against Howard Stern | url= http://www.fmqb.com/article.asp?id=180322 | work= FMQB | date= February 28, 2006 | accessdate= August 25, 2010}} In a press conference held hours before the suit was filed, Stern said it was nothing more than a "personal vendetta" against him by CBS president [[Leslie Moonves]].{{cite news | title= Radio star Howard Stern in ‘Sirius’ legal trouble | url= http://msnbc.msn.com/id/11617416/site/todayshow/ns/today |first= Anne |last= Thompson | publisher= MSNBC | date= March 1, 2006| accessdate= August 25, 2010}} A settlement was reached on May 25, with Sirius paying $2 million to CBS for control of Stern's 20-year broadcast archives.{{cite news | title= Stern Gets Old Tapes, CBS Gets $2M |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/05/25/entertainment/main1654391.shtml?source=RSS&attr=Business_1654391 | work= CBS News | date= May 25, 2006| accessdate= August 25, 2010}} In the same month, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine included Stern in its [[Time 100]] list.{{cite news |last = Spade |first = David |url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1187317,00.html |title = Howard Stern New King Of Satellite |work= Time |date=May 2006 |accessdate= August 25, 2010}} He also ranked seventh in [[Forbes]]' [[Celebrity 100]] list in June 2006,{{cite news |title = Top 100 Most Powerful Celebrities - Howard Stern |work = Forbes |url = http://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/53/5S85.html |date=June 2006 |accessdate= August 25, 2010}} and reappeared in 2011 at number 26.{{cite news |url=http://www.forbes.com/wealth/celebrities/list |title= The World's Most Powerful Celebrities |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=June 6, 2011}} Stern signed a new contract with Sirius to continue his show for five more years in December 2010.{{cite news | title= Howard Stern to stay with Sirius Satellite Radio; signs new five-year contract |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/2010/12/09/2010-12-09_howard_stern_to_stay_with_sirius_satellite_radio_signs_new_fiveyear_contract.html | work= [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] | date= December 9, 2010 | accessdate= December 9, 2010 | first=Richard | last=Huff}} Following the agreement, Stern and his agent filed a lawsuit against Sirius on March 22, 2011, for allegedly failing to pay stock bonuses promised to them from the past four years while helping the company exceed subscriber growth targets. Sirius said it was "surprised and disappointed" by the suit.{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=13195363 |title=Stern sues Sirius over bonus pay for subscribers |publisher=ABC News |date=March 22, 2011 |accessdate=March 23, 2011}} On April 17, 2012, New York Judge Barbara Kapnick "granted a SiriusXM motion for summary judgment, dismissing the lawsuit."{{cite web |url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/documents/howard-stern-lawsuit-dismissed-9785612 |title=Howard Stern’s $300 Million Lawsuit Bounced |publisher=The Smoking Gun |date=April 17, 2012 |accessdate=April 20, 2012}} In May, 2011, Stern announced that he would be broadcasting on a reduced schedule, alternating between three-day and four-day working weeks.{{cite news | title= Howard Stern begins reduced Sirius XM schedule |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/broadcasting/news/a317596/howard-stern-begins-reduced-sirius-xm-schedule.html | work= Digital Spy Limited | date= May 3, 2011 | accessdate= July 30, 2011 | first=Justin | last=Harp}} On December 15 of the same year, Stern announced that he will replace [[Piers Morgan]] as a judge for the [[America's Got Talent (season 7)|seventh season]] of ''[[America's Got Talent]]''. Filming will take place in Newark, New Jersey at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and began in February 2012.{{cite web|title= Howard Stern To Judge On 'America's Got Talent'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1676030/howard-stern-americas-got-talent.jhtml|publisher=MTV|date=December 15, 2011|accessdate=December 15, 2011|first=Gil|last=Kaufman}} ==FCC fines== {{main|FCC fines of The Howard Stern Show}} From 1990 to 2004, the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) has fined owners of radio stations that carried ''The Howard Stern Show'' a total of $3.2 million for [[indecent]] programming.{{cite web |title= Indecency on the Air. Shock-radio jock Howard Stern remains 'King of All Fines' |first= John |last= Dunbar |date= April 9, 2004 |url=http://projects.publicintegrity.org/telecom/report.aspx?aid=239 |publisher= The Center for Public Integrity |accessdate=September 6, 2010}} ==Personal life== [[File:Howard Stern and Beth Ostrosky.jpg|thumb|Stern and Beth Ostrosky in 2011]] Stern married his first wife, Alison (née Berns), on June 4, 1978 at [[Temple Ohabei Shalom (Brookline, Massachusetts)|Temple Ohabei Shalom]] in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]].Hoffman, Matthew. ''The Completely Unauthorized Howard Stern'' (Courage Books, 1998), ISBN 978-0-7624-0377-6, p. 25 They have three daughters: Emily Beth (b. 1983), Debra Jennifer (b. 1986) and Ashley Jade (b. 1993).{{cite web|url=http://www.sirius.com/servlet/ContentServer?pagename=Sirius/Page&c=FlexContent&cid=1134268004584 |title=Meet: The Cast |accessdate=September 18, 2008 |last=Phillips |first=Erica |date=February 21, 2006 |publisher=Sirius Satellite Radio |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060221193103/http://www.sirius.com/servlet/ContentServer?pagename=Sirius/Page&c=FlexContent&cid=1134268004584 |archivedate=February 21, 2006}} On October 22, 1999, Stern announced their decision to separate.{{cite news |title=Stern's Dating Rating Game |first= David |last=Hinkley | date=February 8, 2000 | work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] | url =http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2000/02/08/2000-02-08_stern_s_dating_rating_game_h.html | accessdate = May 7, 2010}} The marriage ended in 2001 with an amicable divorce and settlement.[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/14/AR2007021401507.html "Howard Stern Engaged To Model Girlfriend"], [[Associated Press]] via ''[[The Washington Post]]'', February 14, 2007. Retrieved September 18, 2008. In 2000, Stern began to date model [[Beth Ostrosky Stern|Beth Ostrosky]], co-host of ''[[Casino Cinema]]'' from 2004 to 2007.{{citation needed|date=March 2011}} She also frequently appeared in the American edition of ''[[FHM]]''.{{cite web | last = Reiter | first = Amy | publisher = Salon.com | title = The Fix | date= June 1, 2005 | url = http://dir.salon.com/story/ent/col/fix/2005/06/01/wed/index.html | accessdate = September 2007 }} On February 14, 2007 Stern announced their engagement. They married on October 3, 2008, at [[Le Cirque]] restaurant in New York City.{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/10032008/news/regionalnews/howard_stern_wedding_at_hand_132013.htm|title=Howard Stern Gets Married| first=Erin | last=Calabrese | work =The New York Post |date=October 3, 2008 |accessdate=October 3, 2008}} Stern's parents developed an interest in [[Transcendental Meditation]], which they shared with Howard. He practices it to this day.Colford, p. 29. He credits it with aiding him in quitting smoking and achieving his goals in radio.{{cite web|url=http://awearnessblog.com/2009/03/howard-stern-transcendental-meditation.php |title=Howard Stern And Transcendental Meditation |accessdate=September 18, 2008 |last= Mwangaguhunga |first=Ron |date=February 21, 2006 |publisher=Awarenessblog}} Stern interviewed the late [[Maharishi Mahesh Yogi]], founder of the [[Transcendental Meditation technique|technique]], twice.{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} Stern also plays on the [[Internet Chess Club]], and has taken lessons from chess master [[Dan Heisman]], although he has recently claimed to have quit playing.
